sub_topic: Finding the inverse of a matrix
message_1:
Find the inverse of the following 2x2 matrix:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 \end{bmatrix} $$
message_2:
To find the inverse of a 2x2 matrix, we can use the following formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix}$$

where A is the given matrix:

$$A = \begin{bmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 5 \\ 6 & 7 \end{bmatrix}$$

First, we need to find the determinant of A (det(A)):

$$\text{det}(A) = ad - bc = (4)(7) - (5)(6) = 28 - 30 = -2$$

Now, we can find the inverse of A using the formula:

$$A^{-1} = \frac{1}{\text{det}(A)} \begin{bmatrix} d & -b \\ -c & a \end{bmatrix} = \frac{1}{-2} \begin{bmatrix} 7 & -5 \\ -6 & 4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{7}{2} & \frac{5}{2} \\ 3 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$$

So, the inverse of the given matrix is:

$$A^{-1} = \begin{bmatrix} -\frac{7}{2} & \frac{5}{2} \\ 3 & -2 \end{bmatrix}$$
